The problem of commitment in a dynamic regulatory framework was considered by Baron and Besanko (1987) when they modelled the behaviour of a regulator and firm in the absence of complete information. In a dynamic framework, the regulator is able to observe firm behaviour as time progresses which reveals information about costs and, consequently, there is an incentive for the regulator to change policy.
